title: 1968-C
statement: C. Assembly via Remainderstime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given an array $$$x_2,x_3,\\dots,x_n$$$. Your task is to findanyarray $$$a_1,\\dots,a_n$$$, where:$$$1\\le a_i\\le 10^9$$$ for all $$$1\\le i\\le n$$$.$$$x_i=a_i \\bmod a_{i-1}$$$ for all $$$2\\le i\\le n$$$.Here $$$c\\bmod d$$$ denotes the remainder of the division of the integer $$$c$$$ by the integer $$$d$$$. For example $$$5 \\bmod 2 = 1$$$, $$$72 \\bmod 3 = 0$$$, $$$143 \\bmod 14 = 3$$$.Note that if there is more than one $$$a$$$ which satisfies the statement, you are allowed to find any.InputThe first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ $$$(1\\le t\\le 10^4)$$$ — the number of test cases.The first line of each test case contains a single integer $$$n$$$ $$$(2\\le n\\le 500)$$$ — the number of elements in $$$a$$$.The second line of each test case contains $$$n-1$$$ integers $$$x_2,\\dots,x_n$$$ $$$(1\\le x_i\\le 500)$$$ — the elements of $$$x$$$.It is guaranteed that the sum of values $$$n$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$2 \\cdot 10^5$$$.OutputFor each test case output any $$$a_1,\\dots,a_n$$$ ($$$1 \\le a_i \\le 10^9$$$) which satisfies the statement.ExampleInput542 4 131 164 2 5 1 2250031 5Output3 5 4 9 2 5 11 5 14 16 5 11 24 501 500 2 7 5NoteIn the first test case $$$a=[3,5,4,9]$$$ satisfies the conditions, because:$$$a_2\\bmod a_1=5\\bmod 3=2=x_2$$$;$$$a_3\\bmod a_2=4\\bmod 5=4=x_3$$$;$$$a_4\\bmod a_3=9\\bmod 4=1=x_4$$$;

processed.result:
You are given a sequence of numbers $x_2, x_3, ..., x_n$.  Your task is to find a sequence of numbers $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$ where:

*  $1 \le a_i \le 10^9$ for all $i$ from 1 to $n$.
*  $x_i = a_i \bmod a_{i-1}$ for all $i$ from 2 to $n$.

Here, $c \bmod d$ means the remainder when the integer $c$ is divided by the integer $d$.

For example, $5 \bmod 2 = 1$, $72 \bmod 3 = 0$, and $143 \bmod 14 = 3$.

You can find any sequence $a$ that satisfies these conditions.

**Input:**

* The first line contains a single integer $t$ (1 ≤ $t$ ≤ 10,000) - the number of test cases.
* The first line of each test case contains a single integer $n$ (2 ≤ $n$ ≤ 500) - the number of elements in the sequence $a$.
* The second line of each test case contains $n-1$ integers $x_2, x_3, ..., x_n$ (1 ≤ $x_i$ ≤ 500) - the elements of the sequence $x$.

**Output:**

For each test case, output any sequence $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$ (1 ≤ $a_i$ ≤ 10⁹) that satisfies the conditions.

You are given a list of numbers.  You need to find another list of numbers where each number in the second list is the remainder when dividing the next number in the second list by the previous number in the second list.  The numbers in the second list can be any number between 1 and 1 billion.
